description: From translingual Grandiflora, from New Latin grandiflōra, the feminine form, following the feminine gender of rosa (“rose”), of grandiflōrus (“having large flowers”), from grandis (“large”) +‎ flōs (“flower”, stem flōr-)  +‎ -us (suffix forming adjectives; feminine -a).

entries.meaning: A rose of the Grandiflora class of roses created in the middle of the 20th century as backcrosses of hybrid teas and floribundas that fit neither category.
